a.href: textview.html?location=塞 is to "hinder/obstruct", surely not "boost"? I read this very differently than Lynn, the idea is that (following Cheng Xuanying) if one promotes 德 it hinders the natural functioning of one's 性. It appears he is following Wang Shumin's emendation. However, Cheng Xuanying and the earlier commentators straightforwardly read 塞. He is letting the later textual scholarship guide his translation here, despite his claim to read it as Guo Xiang would have.

a.href: textview.html?location=子路是孔门一期的学生，大师兄。他的优点是直率，缺点是莽撞。孔子呵斥他，意思是说，什么叫"知之"，我不是讲过了吗？你难道忘了吗？知道的就说知道，不知道的就说不知道，这才叫知道。话有点像绕口令。我估计，子路肯定是说了什么冒失话，所以孔子才这么讲。治学之难在于，我们常常分不清我们知道什么和不知道什么，特别是不知道我们不知道什么。《庄子·齐物论》有一段问答，啮缺问王倪，有三个问题，第一个问题，万物是不是有一样的标准？王倪说，我怎么知道？第二个问题，你知道你不知道什么吗？王倪说，我怎么知道？第三个问题，万物不69能互相理解吗？王倪说，我怎么知道？三问三不知。他说，我也想试着讲一讲，但我怎么知道我知道的就一定不是我不知道的，我不知道的就一定不是我知道的呢？孔子也喜欢说"不知"，但并非真的不知道，而是知道也不告诉你，借以表示不满（参看《八佾》３．１１）

a.href: textview.html?location=Bringing 妖 and 夭 together is a case of paronomasia. Cf. Xu Shen's 許慎 (1st cent. CE–after 120) <Shuowen jiezi> 說文解字 (ca. 100 CE): Xu Shen's definition of <nie> (written 蠥) was visibly influenced by the same material as that used by Ban Gu, if not directly by Ban Gu’s monograph itself: "One speaks of 'deviance' for strangeness in garments, in songs and rhyme, and in plants; of 'anomaly' for strangeness in wild beasts and legged animals [such as] locust" 衣服歌謠艸木之怪謂之䄏；禽獸蟲蝗之怪謂之蠥 (<Shuowen jiezi>, 283a). [禽獸 includes all non-domestic birds and quadrupeds, hence my "wild beasts".] Dictionaries usually consider Xu Shen's spelling (䄏 and 蠥) and Ban Gu’s (妖 and 孽) to be equivalent.

a.href: textview.html?location=道基:〔一〕黃震曰：「道基言天地既位，而列聖制作之功。」戴彥升曰：「道基篇原本天地，歷敘先聖，終論仁義。知伯杖威任力而亡，秦二世尚刑而亡，語在其中，蓋即面折高帝語，退而奏之，故為第一篇也。」唐晏曰：「此篇歷敘前古帝王，而總之以仁義。」器案：本書慎微篇：「夫大道履之而行，則無不能，故謂之道。」論衡本性篇引陸賈曰：「天地生人也，以禮義之性；人能察己所以受命則順，順之謂道。」意謂順應自然之道也。此文言道基，義亦相會。

a.href: textview.html?location=1.This line is called the outline of tai yang disease, a name that has been agreed by contemporary scholars and practitioners, because it summarizes important features of the exterior syndrome in tai yang disease in regard to clinical manifestations based on understanding of the direct relationship between the exterior syndrome in tai yang disease and the distribution of tai yang channels. Likewise, the first line of other diseases in Discussion of Cold Damage, apart from yang ming disease, is called outline of such disease. Wu Qian and colleagues explicitly pointed out that “putting this line on the first one is to serve as the outline of tai yang disease. Whenever tai yang disease is discussed in the three sections of tai yang conformation, all refers to symptoms, signs and the pulse in this line.”
